chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: Hello, welcome to lesson 5 of module 1 of my new course on networking fundamentals.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: This module will teach you everything you need to understand how data flows through

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: the internet.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: In this lesson we'll be picking apart routers, and we'll show you everything routers do

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: to facilitate communication between networks.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: Before watching this lesson, it is recommended to have watched the prior lessons in this

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: series.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: In lesson 1, we discussed the concept of networks.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: We defined them as a logical grouping of hosts.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: We mentioned that each network has its own IP address space, and each host has an IP

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: address in that network's IP address space.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: We also defined switching as the process of moving data within networks, and then we defined

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: routing as the process of moving data between networks.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: A router, which is going to be the focus of today's lesson, is simply a device whose primary

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: purpose is routing.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: Then in lesson 2, we discussed the OSI model.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: We used this illustration to discuss the interaction of layer 2 and layer 3.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: We showed you that for this host to send some data to this host, it would start by adding

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: a layer 3 header, which included a source and destination IP address of the two endpoints

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: of the conversation.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: Then a new layer 2 header is added to facilitate each hop along the path between the two endpoints.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: All of this was discussed in detail in lesson 2.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: Then in lesson 3, we focused on hosts, and we showed you everything hosts do when speaking

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: to other hosts.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: We first showed you everything hosts do to speak to other hosts in the same network,

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: regardless of how they are connected.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: Then we showed you everything hosts do to speak to other hosts in foreign networks,

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: regardless of how they are connected.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: Both of these illustrations allowed us to discuss ARP, or the address resolution protocol,

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: and show you ARP's role in internet communication.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: All of this is the prerequisite knowledge you'll need to fully understand this lesson.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: If any of these concepts are unfamiliar to you, please check out the first three lessons

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: of this course.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: There are links in the description.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: In this lesson, we're going to be focusing on routers, and we're going to show you everything

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: that routers do to move data across the internet.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: Here is a network with two hosts.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: Each of these hosts have a MAC address, and is configured with an IP address in this network's

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: IP address space.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: For these hosts to speak to each other, they would have to be connected to a switch.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: And this switch will facilitate all the communication within this network.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: But for these hosts to speak to a foreign network, we would have to add a router.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: Now routers are also connected to a network, which means routers, just like hosts, also

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: have an IP address and a MAC address.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: And all the rules of layer 2 and layer 3 that we've discussed prior still apply in order

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: for these hosts to speak to this router.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: Now in order to keep things simple and reduce the variables, since we've already talked

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: about switches in the last lesson, we're going to leave switches out of this lesson entirely.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: But everything we discussed about how switches work still apply, so feel free to watch lesson

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: 4 if you want to understand how that works.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: In this lesson, we're just going to be focusing on routers.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: Now if routers have an IP address and a MAC address, just like hosts, what then is the

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: real difference between a router and a host?

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: Well my favorite definition for routers and hosts actually comes from the IPv6 RFC.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: If you're unfamiliar with RFCs, they stand for Request For Comments, and they are the

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: type of document that define internet standards.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: In fact, if you're ever in a nerd argument with someone, and you are debating about how

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: something in the networking world works, whoever can quote the RFC always wins, because the

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: RFC is literally the instructions that were used to build the internet.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: In any case, RFC 2460 is the IPv6 RFC, but it provides a useful definition for hosts

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: and routers that also applies to IPv4.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: The RFC defines a node as anything which implements IP, or anything with an IP address.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: It then defines a router as any node that forwards packets not addressed to itself,

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: which leaves the definition of a host to be a node that is simply not a router.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: So the real difference between a router and a host is that routers forward packets not

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: destined to themselves.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: That is how they are different from hosts.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: For example, if this packet were to magically appear on this network and arrive on host

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: D, host D would take a look at the destination IP address and realize that it is not itself,

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: and would simply drop this packet.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: But if this packet were to arrive on router 1, router 1 would recognize that it is not

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: destined to itself, but would still try and deliver this packet to the appropriate destination.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: That is how hosts and routers are different.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: Now of course, for router 1 to actually forward packets not destined to itself, there has

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: to be another network that exists.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: So let's go ahead and add another network to our topology.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: A moment ago, we said that routers have an IP address and a MAC address.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: That in fact is what is meant by router 1 being connected to a particular network.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: But now that we have another network, router 1 is going to need another IP address and

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: MAC address in order to be connected to the new network.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: Here we've configured router 1 with the IP address 10.0.5.5.1, and that is what officially

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: connects router 1 to this new network.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: In order to accomplish this goal, routers must maintain a map of all networks that they

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: know about.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: This map is known as the routing table.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: Inside a routing table is what's known as routes, and each route is merely a set of

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: instructions for how to reach a specific network.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: For our topology over here, there are two networks, 10.0.5.5 and 10.0.4.4, and router

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: 1 is going to have a route correlating to each of those networks.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: The first route will tell router 1 that to reach anything in the 10.0.5.5.x network,

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: router 1 should send that packet out the left interface.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: And the second route will tell router 1 that to reach anything in the 10.0.4.4 network,

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: router 1 should use its right interface.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: Normally, the interfaces of the router would be slightly more technical, something like

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: FA01 or GIG02 or ETH0 or ETH3.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: But to keep things simple in this presentation, we're just going to use left and right to

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: indicate the left interface or the right interface of the router.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: So that is a basic rundown of routers, and specifically the routing table.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: The routing table is actually a very important concept in networking.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: In fact, a large part of a network engineer's job is to ensure that every router has the

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: proper routes in its routing table in order to move packets through a network.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: Therefore, we're going to spend a bit more time digging into the concept of a routing

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: table and discussing the different methods that routes are learned.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: There are three ways that routes can be populated in a routing table.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: The first method is what's known as directly connected.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: A directly connected route exists for every network that a router is directly attached to.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: In the case of R1, R1 is directly connected to two different networks, and therefore will

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: have two different directly connected routes in its routing table.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: The first one telling R1 that the 10.0.5.5 network exists out the left interface, and

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: the second one telling R1 that the 10.0.4.4 network exists out the right interface.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: Now, if this is familiar to you, it's because it's the exact same thing we had a moment

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: ago when we looked at R1's routing table, except this is a more formal way of displaying

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: a route.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: Now, let's add another network and another router to our topology.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: Here we have R2 in between the 10.0.6.6 network and the 10.0.5.5 network.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: Each router is going to maintain its own routing table, which means router 2 has its

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: own routing table that is independent from router 1's.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: In each case, the routing table is a map of every network that router knows about.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: Just like before with R1, in order to attach R1 to the 10.0.4.4 and the 10.0.5.5 network,

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: we have to configure an IP address in each of those networks.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: The same thing will apply with R2.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: For R2 to be attached to the 10.0.5.5 network, we're going to have to plug R2 in and then

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: configure an IP address in this network.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: In this case, we've configured the IP address 10.0.5.5.2.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: This created a directly connected route in R2's routing table, telling R2 that the existence

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: of the 10.0.5.5 network exists out R2's right interface.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: In the same way, as soon as we configure this IP address on R2's left interface, this adds

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: a new directly connected route to R2's routing table, telling R2 that the 10.0.6.6 network

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: exists out R2's left interface.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: Each of these routers will now use their own routing table to move packets through this

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: topology.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: For example, if this packet shows up from host C with a destination IP address of 10.0.5.5.8,

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: that's host B's IP address, R2 will take a look at its routing table to determine that

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: the 10.0.5.5 network exists out the right interface and will forward that packet along.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: But what happens if host C now sends this packet?

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: Well, this packet has a destination IP address of 10.0.4.4.9.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: That's host A's IP address.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: When Router 2 takes a look at its routing table, it's not going to find an entry for

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: the 10.0.4.4 network.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: At this point, Router 2 does not know how to get to the 10.0.4.4 network, which unfortunately

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: means Router 2 is simply going to drop that packet.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: When a router receives a packet with a destination IP address it doesn't know how to get to,

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: the packet is going to be dropped.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: Remember, from the perspective of each router, the routing table is a map of every network

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: that exists.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: And at this point in time, Router 2 does not know that the 10.0.4.4 network exists.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: And since R2 is not directly attached to the 10.0.4.4 network, it's not going to have

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: a directly connected route in order to get to the 10.0.4.4 network.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: But lucky for us, there are still two other methods that exist for how a routing table

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: can be populated with routes.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: The second method to populate a routing table is what's known as a static route.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: A static route exists anytime an administrator manually provides instructions to a router

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: about the location of a particular network.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: For example, I can log into Router 2 and configure it with a static route, telling Router 2 that

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: any time it wants to reach the 10.0.4.4 network, it should send that packet to the 10.0.5.5.1

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: IP address, which is Router 1's IP address.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: Now if Router 2 receives this packet from host C, it'll take a look at the destination

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: IP address, find a match in its routing table, and forward that packet along to the next

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: router in the path, in this case R1.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: R1 will then take a look at its routing table and determine that this packet should be sent

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: out the right interface where it'll arrive on host A.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: So that's an example of a static route.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: But what happens if host A responds?

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: This response is going to have a destination IP address of 10.0.66.7, which is host C's

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: IP address.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: And when R1 receives this response, it's going to take a look at its routing table.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: And at the moment, Router 1 does not know how to deliver this packet.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: So normally, Router 1 would just drop this packet.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: But just like we use a static route to tell R2 about the 10.0.4.4 network, we can also

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: use a static route to tell R1 about the 10.0.66 network.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: This static route would tell R1 that the 10.0.66 network can be reached by going to

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: the 10.0.55.2 IP address, which is Router 2's IP address.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: With this static route, Router 1 now has instructions on what to do with that packet, which is to

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: send it to R2.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: R2 will then take a look at its routing table to determine that the 10.0.66 network is out

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: the left interface where it'll deliver the packet to host C.

chunks.title: Everything Routers do , Part 1 , Networking Fundamentals , Lesson 5
chunks.text: So notice, we were able to use static routes to tell both of these routers about the networks
